results.title: Le Journal D'un Fou = Diary of a Madman
results.brief_description:
This adaptation of the Russian classic is set in Paris in 1963. Pascal is slowly losing grip on reality. Living in a state of permanent exaltation, he confides all his dreams to his diary, in particular, his ambition to become Ferdinand VIII, King of Spain.

Credits: Producer, Paul Joly ; director, Roger Coggio ; writers, Marcel Moussy, Sylvie Luneau, Roger Coggio ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, George Delerue.

results.title: Le Jour Se Leve = Daybreak
results.brief_description:
Poetic realism is a phrase often used in association with Carne’s work, and there could be no better example of this particular style than ‘Le jour se leve’. The setting is the ‘banlieue’ of a French industrial town - recreated in studio by Alexandre Trauner - and it would be hard to disagree with Gavin Lambert’s comment in ‘Sequence’ in 1948 that ‘there is no other film which has conveyed so intensely the drama, irony and nostalgias of urban life’. The narrative of ‘Le jour se leve’ condenses into one night action which covers a considerably longer period. On the night in question, Francois, a factory worker, has killed Valentin, who has a small music-hall act, and awaits the inevitable arrival of the police. In the meantime, he remembers the events which led up to the murder. Added to the abstract sense of determinism ‘Le jour se leve’ has a social and political dimension reflecting the climate of despair gripping France just prior to WWII. This feeling was particularly acute among the working class which had pinned so much hope on the Popular Front government, only to have them dashed by its too rapid disintegration and by the renewed offensives of the Right. The contrast with earlier films such as Renoir’s ‘Le crime de monsieur Lange’ (1935) and ‘La Marseillaise’ (1938), and even Duvivier’s ‘La belle equipe’ (1936), with their hope and optimism is both striking and depressing. The feeling of comradeship and solidarity is gone. The scene in which Arletty appears naked had to be cut to allow for the film to be released. ‘Le jour se leve’ was then regarded as ‘demoralising’ by the Vichy government which attempeted to ban all films affiliated with the ‘poetic realism’ style. The film was re-made as an American film noir as ‘The Long Night’ (1947) directed by Anatole Litvak, starring Henry Fonda.

Credits: Producer, Paul Madeux ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Jacques Viot ; photography, Curt Courant, Philippe Agostini ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photography, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Arletty, Jacqueline Laurent, Jules Berry, Bernard Blier.

results.title: Le Jongleur de Notre-Dame = the Juggler of Notre-Dame
results.brief_description:
Barnabe is a juggler who performs on fairs and markets with much success. When war starts, Barnabe is given shelter in a monastry. He proves to be of no use around the monks as he has no other skills but juggling.

Credits: Director, Lonati Bettiol ; writer, Maurice Genevoix ; photograhy, Bob Zoubovitch ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Jean Rochefort [narration only].

results.title: Le Grand Ocean
results.brief_description:
Sixteen men decide to take part to the first around the world boat race. This documentary follows them for 8 months, from September 1973 to April 1974, across 3 oceans.

Credits: Directors, writers, Jean-Pierre and Daniel Millet ; photography, Georges Perenoud.

results.title: Le Grand Dadais = the Big Ninny
results.brief_description:
Alain Quesnard is a studious young man of twenty who lives with his mother. One day he meets Patricia, a model. For her and the pleasures she introduces him to he loses his head, his fiancee and finally his freedom. Reference: Film Index International.

Credits: Producer, Michel Cousin ; director, Pierre Granier-Deferre ; writers, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Betrand Poirot-Delpech ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Jacques Perrin, Eva Renzi, Danielle Gaubert, Yvonne Clech, Harald Liepnitz, Yves Renier.

results.title: Le Destin de Juliette = the Destiny of Juliette
results.brief_description:
Aline Isserman’s film chronicles twenty years of a woman’s life. Juliette, a simple country girl, is in love with Pierre, a sheperd but she is forced into a marriage with a boring railway worker in order to save her family from poverty and homelessness. The husband, Marcel, is transferred from post to post, and becomes an alcoholic, eventually dying, leaving Juliette free to rebuild her life.

Credits: Producer, Eric Lambert ; director, Aline Isserman ; writers, Michel Dufresne, Aline Isserman ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Bernard Lubat.
Cast: Laure Duthilleul, Richard Bohringer, Veronique Silver, Pierre Forget, Hippolyte Girardot.

results.title: Le Dernier Matin D'albert Camus
results.brief_description:
The life and work of Albert Camus, Nobel prize-winning novelist, playwright, journalist and essayist. This short documentary returns to places that have played a important role in Camus’ life; the ruins of Tippasa, his home in Lourmarin as well as the theatre which was to be his refuge from the trappings of celebrity. It is illustrated with a lengthy interview with the author. Also available in the NLA Collection (#2002445, 16mm).

Credits: Director, Harry Fishbach ; writers, Daisy Loriaux, Jean-Claude Brisville ; photography, Jean-Marie Boussaguet ; music, Rene Thomas, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Text by Albert Camus interpreted by Michel Auclair, narration by Jacques Harden.

results.title: Le Corbeau = the Raven
results.brief_description:
A small French village is plagued by a poison pen writer, whose principal target is the town doctor. The vitriolic letters wreak so much havoc that soon neighbour turns upon neighbour. Eventually, the doctor himself is suspected of writing the letters, cloaking himself in the respectability of his office. When the psychiatrist starts receiving letters as well, he decides to investigate. Concluding that his own wife is the culprit, he has her committed. But soon after, more letters arrive … ‘Le Corbeau’ is a realistic portrait of Occupied France and its obsession for petty bickering and vengeful denunciation. Produced by the German production company ‘Continental Films’ the film was condemned as unpatriotic after the Liberation, and director Henri-Georges Clouzot was banned from filmmaking until 1947. Le Corbeau’ was remade in Hollywood by Otto Preminger as ‘The 13th Letter’ (1951).

Credits: Producer: Rene Montis ; director: Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writers, Henri-Georges Clouzot, Louis Chavance ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Tony Aubin ; sound, William-Robert Sivel.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Micheline Francey, Ginette Leclerc, Roger Blin, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Pierre Bertin, Pierre Larquey, Jean Brochard, Helene Manson, Noel Roquevert, Louis Seigner, Sylvie.

results.title: Le Ciel Est Bleu = the Sky Is Blue
results.brief_description:
A former war correspondant is given a new assignement as a sports journalist and sent to Dublin to cover a rugby match. While on assignment he meets a former American girlfiend and rekindles their affair.

Credits: Director, Serge Leroy ; writers, Serge Leroy, Myriam Lempereur ; photography, Jean-Jacques Rochut ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Frederic de Pasquale, Alexandra Stewart, Harry Brogan, Brian McGrath, Larbi Essakali, Liam O’Callaghan, Grace O’Shaughnessy.

results.title: Le Chevalier de Pardaillan
results.creator_credit: Bernard Borderie, Andre Haguet and Andre Legrand
results.brief_description:
In 1588, the Duke de Guise and princess Fausta are vying for the crown. Violetta, a young gypsy who has caught the duke’s eyes, is the object of a merciless competition between would-be lovers. When the duke discovers Violetta is of noble origins, he has her kidnapped in order to help in his attempt to overthrow the king. Pardaillan must then intervene to save the king and the damsel in distress.

Credits: Producers, Andre Legrand, Andre Haguet ; director, Bernard Borderie ; writers, Henri Haguet, Bernard Borderie ; photography, Henri Persin ; music, Paul Misraki ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Gerard Barray, Jean Topart, Gianna-Maria Canale, Michele Grellier, Guy Delorme.
